awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Untangling Aboveground versus Belowground Plant Contributions to the Soil Organic Carbon Pool
awd_abstract_narration:
The largest terrestrial reservoir of carbon is in the soil, and most of this carbon comes from plants. Yet, despite its importance, the factors that regulate the movement of carbon from plants to soils remain poorly understood, particularly the relative contribution of leaves and stems versus roots. Assessing the vulnerability of soil carbon to disruption by environmental changes depends on understanding the factors that control aboveground versus belowground carbon from plants. This Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant research will provide funds to conduct laboratory experiments to simulate the movement of plant carbon to the soil, and to quantify how the source of plant carbon dictates its fate in the soil. For example, the researchers will evaluate whether carbon entering the soil from the shoots of the plant is stored more or less effectively than carbon being supplied via roots. The objectives of this work are: 1) to improve global carbon models to better describe the terrestrial carbon cycle, and 2) inform practices in forestry, agriculture, and other types of land management that are looking to maximize the amount of plant carbon stored in soils. The investigators will also train students and develop multimedia outreach activities with a natural history museum to inform the broader public on the relevance of this work. 

Considerable scientific debate exists around the relative roles of aboveground versus belowground plant inputs as sources of soil organic carbon.  This debate must be resolved if the terrestrial carbon cycle is to be accurately modeled because preliminary evidence suggests substantial differences in the fate of above- vs. belowground inputs that may strongly influence rates of accumulation of soil organic carbon pools and their dynamics. This research will conduct empirical studies that test mechanistic differences that underpin aboveground versus belowground plant carbon pathways, independent of the quantity and quality of carbon flowing through them.   This project uses a series of microcosm experiments to test hypotheses about the mechanistic differences in how carbon flows through aboveground and belowground plant pathways to the soil. The common plant carbon compound glucose (isotopically labeled with the heavy stable isotope of carbon) will be added to soil microcosms to assess key differences underlying belowground versus aboveground pathways to the soil carbon pool. This research will deepen knowledge of how soil carbon is formed from plant carbon and improve the ability of models to predict carbon dynamics under future environmental conditions.

por.por_cntn:
How does plant carbon ? the carbon from roots and shoots ? move into the soil and form soil carbon? This seemingly simple question forms one of the most central, yet poorly understood, portions of the terrestrial carbon cycle. In order to understand and predict how changes to terrestrial ecosystems will impact carbon cycling ? such as shifting plant communities, deforestation, and the spread of invasive species? it is necessary to have a basic, mechanistic understanding of the relative amount of plant carbon that is either stabilized in the soil as soil carbon, versus the proportion of the carbon that is returned to the atmosphere as CO2 via microbial respiration or leached through the subsurface.

 

The goal of this project was to track how carbon enters the soil from different sources of plant inputs (either via the aboveground or via the belowground), and to determine what factors influence the retention of that plant carbon in the mineral soil as stable soil carbon. To do so, we created artificial soil profiles in the laboratory ? soil ?rhizoboxes? with artificial, microporous plastic plant roots at their center ? to simulate how carbon flows in from the belowground in temperate forest ecosystems. We experimentally altered the volume, rate, and distance that a common simple carbon compound travels en route to the stable soil carbon pool from belowground versus aboveground plant sources (i.e. atop the soil surface), as well as the density of the soil microbial community where that plant carbon compound enters the mineral soil.

 

We found that the ?slow-drip? approach of belowground rhizosphere carbon ? that is, carbon that gradually and continuously leaves the living plant root directly into the mineral soil ? is a more efficient pathway to the stable soil carbon pool than high-volume pulses of aboveground dissolved organic carbon from the leaf litter layer and organic horizon of a forest, which leach down the soil profile during precipitation events (like rainstorms). We found that this low-volume ?drip? of belowground rhizosphere carbon was more efficiently processed by the rhizosphere microbial community relative to aboveground large pulses of carbon to the bulk soil community. Subsequently, this belowground rhizosphere carbon was more efficiently converted to microbial-derived, stable soil carbon than was aboveground carbon.

 

We also conducted a follow-up study to specifically focus on ? and directly manipulate ? the density of the soil microbial community. We identified microbial density as a key variable controlling soil carbon formation because much of stable soil carbon is derived from dead microbial biomass, and because there is much variation in soil microbial density across different regions of the soil: i.e. around the living root (the rhizosphere), the dead root (detritusphere), and the surrounding soil (bulk soil). In this study, we found that whether a particular plant carbon compound was retained as stable soil carbon was dependent on both the chemistry of the specific carbon compound, as well as the density of the soil microbial community at the point it entered the mineral soil. This means that certain plant compounds, like simple sugars, may be more efficiently converted to stable soil carbon via the ?microbial formation pathway? in regions of high microbial density, like the rhizosphere. In contrast, other compounds ? such as breakdown products of the plant-structural compound called lignin (e.g. vanillin) ? may be more efficiently stabilized in regions of the soil with lower microbial density, as they can more strongly sorb to mineral surfaces but are inefficiently processed by the microbial community.

 

Our work supported the development of a doctoral student, generating lead-author published papers and conference talks at leading, international meetings, as well as the training of two undergraduates. The results of our work can be applied to models of the terrestrial carbon cycle, both at the scale of the ecosystem and at the scale of the Earth system. Improving models of carbon cycling requires lab-based, mechanistic studies that test the assumptions implicit in these models. Therefore, by identifying and testing different features and controls of the pathways by which plant carbon is converted to stable soil carbon, we can more accurately portray how soil carbon stabilization occurs. Moreover, we can ideally better predict how soil carbon stocks might respond to the wide suite of environmental changes occurring in terrestrial ecosystems over the course of this century.
